title: Procol Harum's 1967 hit, 'A Whiter Shade Of Pale,' is one of the best selling songs of all time selling over 10 million copies worldwide. What makes this song such an enduring classic? - Quora

response.answer_text: I was 16 at the time, and can give you the reason it struck me immediately. This was the year of “Sgt. Peppers” (by some little band), of “Disraeli Gears” (Cream), of “Are You Experienced” (Hendrix), “Surrealistic Pillow” (Jefferson Airplane), of “The Doors.” Pop music was moving ‘experimental’, ‘underground’, ‘avant garde’, ‘heavy-blues’ … things were getting serious. And in comes this ‘serious piece’ — “Whiter Shade of Pale.” With a ‘classical music feel’ in the Baroque Hammond-Organ instumental theme, played by founding band member Matthew Fisher (who’d had classical training). And a very bluesey voice (songwriter and band leader Gary Booker - who also has the virtue of sharing my birthday!). And very avant-garde lyrics (thanks to lyricist Keith Reid). It landed smack-dab into the middle of the ‘feel of the day’ … just perfectly. And … it is a great melodic song. (it’s too bad IMO that Fisher never got a songwriting credit for it ... this is mentioned by Geoff Menzer below … re the lawsuit … Booker wrote the song, but the long-and-repeated organ riff is a huge part of the musical-memory of it). A little on Procol Harum's great drummer BJ Wilson: When BJ took the Procol Harum gig in 1967, he’d been part (since the breakup of the Paramounts in ‘66) of a ‘studio band’ consisting of himself, a guy named Cat Stevens, and a girl who went by just one name, Lulu. And when Jimmy Page was putting together The New Yardbirds in ‘68 (aka Led Zep), the first guy he asked to be the drummer was … Wilson — who declined, having just recently helped form the ‘permanent lineup’ for Procol Harum. … that would’ve changed the character of what was to come with Zep, no doubt. DID YOU KNOW: in mid-1967, procol Harum was being touted as ‘the next Beatles’ (many bands got saddled with that moniker as time went on …) … “Whiter Shade of Pale” was (Fabber) Paul-n-Linda’s 'song' (they’d just become a couple). Once The Beatles went ‘poof’, Procol Harum became my favorite band for a couple years — as long as they also had their great blues guitarist, Robin Trower (through 1971 IIRC). Their 1970 Home album is one of the best-ever. Here’s one of my very-favorite pieces by them (and it does show them playing ‘live’, stick with it), one of the few that featured Trower’s guitar-playing: “Long Gone Geek” (from Salty Dog, 1969).  (and, of course, “Whiter Shade of Pale”)

The late sixties was a time of invention, a time of endless creativity, a time of hope, a time of a belief in a better world. ‘To be there was to remember, so lay it down again. Mehar Baba lives again, candles in the rain’. Bach notwithstanding, the lyrics are as ghostly and ephemeral as their subject. Meaningless but somehow pregnant with import. This was the era of ‘drugs’ but not the drugs of an earlier era. No longer the coke or horse of the jazz era but rather the bennies or LSD of a more ‘enlightened’ age. ‘Hey Joe’, ‘Itchycoo Park’, ‘Race with the devil’, ‘Grocer Jack, Grocer Jack, get off your back . . . ’, ‘Gin House Blues’, ‘The house of the Rising Sun’, ‘White Rabbit’, ‘Set the controls for the heart of the sun . . . ‘ and then came ‘Woodstock’. To be there was to remember; and I remember. Perhaps it is old fogeys like me that keep the memory alive; perhaps merely Bach’s melody. Always one for a suitable tune, Johann Sebastian! ‘A whiter shade of pale’ came amidst so much other than a simple song could ever relay. The Viet Nam war and later Ohio; 4 dead in Ohio. As much as the British might have wanted to distance themselves from Indo-China, they were politically embroiled. And the music playing youth knew it!
